title: Tech giants facing international tax crackdown as OECD shakes up rules
text:
Technology titans such as Facebook and Amazon face a global crackdown under the biggest shake-up of tax rules in a century.

The proposals would force big businesses to pay more tax in countries where they generate 'significant' sales and profits – even if they do not have a physical presence there.

The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), a group of the world's richest nations, said the overhaul was necessary to make the international tax system fit for the digital age.

Crackdown: Apple chief exec Tim Cook, left, and Facebook boss Mark Zuckerberg, right, look set to be squeezed for more tax thanks to the OECD shake-up

It comes amid mounting anger at multinationals that cynically shift profits around the world to minimise bills, with internet giants accused of being some of the worst offenders.

The OECD has pushed for a global agreement on the issue after several countries, such as the UK, threatened to impose their own taxes.

It said the plans, published yesterday and now out for consultation, were the result of talks involving some 130 nations.

Pay up: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos and girlfriend Lauren Sanchez

But they must be agreed by governments before implementation.

Angel Gurria, the OECD's secretary general, said: 'We're making real progress to address the tax challenges.

Failure to reach agreement by 2020 would greatly increase the risk that countries will act unilaterally, with negative consequences on an already fragile global economy. We must not allow that to happen.'

Nearly £200billion is lost from tax revenues every year because of avoidance efforts by multinationals, says the OECD.

It claimed its proposals amounted to the biggest shake-up of corporate tax rules since the 1920s.

European regulators have targeted companies including Apple and Amazon over tax, arguing they struck illegal 'sweetheart' deals with the Irish and Luxembourg governments and ordering them to pay back billions.

But the OECD said the problem should be tackled by a new system that would see firms pay a country taxes based on how much business they did there, regardless of whether they had staff or offices there.

Countries like the UK, where technology firms rake in billions of pounds, stand to benefit from the proposal whereas low-tax jurisdictions such as Ireland and Luxembourg would lose out.

However the idea could still become derailed if battles break out between countries over how the new rules will be defined.

The plans were welcomed yesterday by some technology firms, with Facebook and Amazon saying they supported the OECD's efforts. But critics claimed the proposals did not go far enough.
description: The proposals would force big businesses, such a Mark Zuckerberg's social media giant Facebook, to pay more tax in countries where they generate 'significant' sales and profits.
authors: Matt Oliver For The Daily Mail
